head.title: Electron momentum distribution of a single mobile hole in the t-J model

article.h1: Electron momentum distribution of a single mobile hole in the t𝑡italic-tt-J𝐽italic-JJ model

span.span:
J. Stefan Institute, SI-1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, University of Ljubljana, SI-1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
J. Stefan Institute, SI-1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia

div.p: We investigate the electron momentum distribution function (EMDF) for the two-dimensional t𝑡italic-tt-J𝐽italic-JJ model. The results are based on the self-consistent Born approximation (SCBA) for the self-energy and the wave function. In the Ising limit of the model we give the results in a closed form, in the Heisenberg limit the results are obtained numerically. An anomalous momentum dependence of EMDF is found and the anomaly is in the lowest order in number of magnons expressed analitycally. We interpret the anomaly as a fingerprint of an emerging large Fermi surface coexisting with hole pockets.

The electron momentum distribution function n𝐤=⟨Ψ𝐤0|∑σc𝐤,σ†⁢c𝐤,σ|Ψ𝐤0⟩subscript𝑛𝐤quantum-operator-productsubscriptΨsubscript𝐤0subscript𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑐𝐤𝜎†subscript𝑐𝐤𝜎subscriptΨsubscript𝐤0italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:langle Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k PUNCT:, italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k PUNCT:, italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:ranglen_{\bf k}=\langle\Psi_{{\bf k}_{0}}|\sum_{\sigma}c_{{\bf k},\sigma}^{\dagger}c% _{{\bf k},\sigma}|\Psi_{{\bf k}_{0}}\rangle is the key quantity for resolving the structure of the Fermi surface in cuprates [1]. Here we study the EMDF for |Ψ𝐤0⟩ketsubscriptΨsubscript𝐤0VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle|\Psi_{{\bf k}_{0}}\rangle which represents a weakly doped antiferromagnet (AFM), i.e., it is the ground state (GS) wave function of a planar AFM with one hole and with the total momentum 𝐤0subscript𝐤0bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf k}_{0}. In the present work we investigate the low-energy physics of the CuO22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} planes in cuprates within the framework of the standard t𝑡italic-tt-J𝐽italic-JJ model

CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-J SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than italic-i italic-j RELOP:greater-than POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-gamma ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end OPEN:( italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] PUNCT:,

div.p: where c~i,σ†superscriptsubscript~𝑐𝑖𝜎†OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-c ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i PUNCT:, italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:dagger POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\tilde{c}}_{i,\sigma}^{\dagger} (c~i,σsubscript~𝑐𝑖𝜎OVERACCENT:tilde ARG:start italic-c ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i PUNCT:, italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\tilde{c}}_{i,\sigma}) are electron creation (annihilation) operators acting in a space forbidding double occupancy on the same site. Siαsubscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛼𝑖italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endS^{\alpha}_{i} are spin operators. Our approach is based on a spinless fermion Schwinger boson representation of the t𝑡italic-tt-J𝐽italic-JJ Hamiltonian [2] and on the SCBA for calculating the Green’s function G𝐤⁢(ω)subscript𝐺𝐤𝜔italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:)G_{\bf k}(\omega) [2, 3, 4] and the corresponding wave function |Ψ𝐤⟩ketsubscriptΨ𝐤VERTBAR:| Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle|\Psi_{{\bf k}}\rangle [5].

In general the expectation value n𝐤subscript𝑛𝐤italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\bf k} has to be calculated numerically. The Ising limit, γ=0𝛾0italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\gamma=0, is an exception. The quasi particle is dispersionless with the GS energy ϵ𝐤=ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐤subscriptitalic-ϵ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{\bf k}=\epsilon_{0}, the residue Z𝐤=Z0subscript𝑍𝐤subscript𝑍0italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endZ_{\bf k}=Z_{0} and the Green’s function G𝐤⁢(ω)=G0⁢(ω)subscript𝐺𝐤𝜔subscript𝐺0𝜔italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:)G_{\bf k}(\omega)=G_{0}(\omega). Therefore it is possible to express the required matrix elements in n𝐤subscript𝑛𝐤italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\bf k} analytically and to perform a summation of corresponding non-crossing contributions to any order n→∞→𝑛italic-n ARROW:to ID:infinityn\to\infty. The result is

math.alttext: \displaystyle 1-\frac{1}{2}Z_{0}(\delta_{{\bf k}{\bf k}_{0}}+\delta_{{\bf k}{% \bf k}_{0}+{\bf Q}})+{1\over N}\delta n_{\bf k},

\displaystyle 1-\frac{1}{2}Z_{0}(\delta_{{\bf k}{\bf k}_{0}}+\delta_{{\bf k}{% \bf k}_{0}+{\bf Q}})+{1\over N}\delta n_{\bf k},

NUMBER:4 italic-P italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where P=∑m=0∞Am⁢Am+1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑚0subscript𝐴𝑚subscript𝐴𝑚1italic-P RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:endP=\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\sqrt{A_{m}A_{m+1}} with A0=Z0subscript𝐴0subscript𝑍0italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{0}=Z_{0}, Am=Am-1⁢[2⁢t⁢G0⁢(ϵ0-2⁢m⁢J)]2subscript𝐴𝑚subscript𝐴𝑚1superscriptdelimited-[]2𝑡subscript𝐺0subscriptitalic-ϵ02𝑚𝐽2italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ NUMBER:2 italic-t italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 italic-m italic-J CLOSE:) CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endA_{m}=A_{m-1}[2tG_{0}(\epsilon_{0}-2mJ)]^{2}, ∑m=0∞Am=1superscriptsubscript𝑚0subscript𝐴𝑚1SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}A_{m}=1 [5] and γ𝐤=(cos⁡kx+cos⁡ky)/2subscript𝛾𝐤subscript𝑘𝑥subscript𝑘𝑦2italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\gamma_{\bf k}=(\cos k_{x}+\cos k_{y})/2. We note that the result Eqs. (2,3) exactly fulfills the sum rule ∑𝐤n𝐤=N-1subscript𝐤subscript𝑛𝐤𝑁1SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-N ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1\sum_{\bf k}n_{\bf k}=N-1 and δ⁢n𝐤≤1𝛿subscript𝑛𝐤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1\delta n_{\bf k}\leq 1. In Eq. (2) the only dependence on the GS momentum 𝐤0subscript𝐤0bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf k}_{0} enters through the two delta functions separated with the AFM vector 𝐐=(π,π)𝐐𝜋𝜋bold-Q RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-pi PUNCT:, italic-pi CLOSE:){\bf Q}=(\pi,\pi). The EMDF δ⁢n𝐤𝛿subscript𝑛𝐤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k} is determined only with two parameters, P𝑃italic-PP and Z0subscript𝑍0italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endZ_{0}, presented as a function of J/t𝐽𝑡italic-J MULOP:divide italic-tJ/t in Fig. 1. Note that P=1𝑃1italic-P RELOP:equals NUMBER:1P=1 and Z0=0subscript𝑍00italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0Z_{0}=0 for J→0→𝐽0italic-J ARROW:to NUMBER:0J\to 0, therefore the result simplifies, δ⁢n𝐤=4⁢γ𝐤⁢(1-γ𝐤)𝛿subscript𝑛𝐤4subscript𝛾𝐤1subscript𝛾𝐤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4 italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\delta n_{\bf k}=4\gamma_{\bf k}(1-\gamma_{\bf k}).

Now we turn to the Heisenberg model, γ→1→𝛾1italic-gamma ARROW:to NUMBER:1\gamma\!\!\to\!\!1. Here the important ingredient is the gap-less magnons with linear dispersion and a more complex ground state of the planar AFM. G𝐤⁢(ω)subscript𝐺𝐤𝜔italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:)G_{\bf k}(\omega) is strongly 𝐤𝐤bold-k{\bf k}-dependent. The GS is fourfold degenerate and the results must be averaged over the GS momenta 𝐤0=(±π/2,±π/2)subscript𝐤0plus-or-minus𝜋2plus-or-minus𝜋2bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:){\bf k}_{0}=(\pm\pi/2,\pm\pi/2). To get more insight into the structure of δ⁢n𝐤𝛿subscript𝑛𝐤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}, we simplify the wave function by keeping only the one-magnon contributions. The leading order contribution to δ⁢n𝐤𝛿subscript𝑛𝐤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k} is then

semantics.annotation: italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:[ NUMBER:2 italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:] PUNCT:,

div.p: with 𝐪=𝐤-𝐤0𝐪𝐤subscript𝐤0bold-q RELOP:equals bold-k ADDOP:minus bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf q}={\bf k}-{\bf k}_{0} [or equivalent in the Brillouin zone (BZ)], 𝐯=t⁢(sin⁡k0⁢x,sin⁡k0⁢y)𝐯𝑡subscript𝑘0𝑥subscript𝑘0𝑦bold-v RELOP:equals italic-t OPEN:( TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, TRIGFUNCTION:sine italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 italic-y POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){\bf v}=t(\sin k_{0x},\sin k_{0y}), M𝐤0⁢𝐪subscript𝑀subscript𝐤0𝐪italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{{\bf k}_{0}{\bf q}} is the hole-magnon coupling and u𝐪subscript𝑢𝐪italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endu_{\bf q} is the ususal spin wave Bogoliubov coefficient [2, 3]. The momentum dependence of the EMDF, contained in Eq. (4), essentially captures well the full numerical solution [6]. A surprising observation is that the EMDF exhibits in the extreme Heisenberg limit a discontinuity ∼Z𝐤0⁢N1/2similar-toabsentsubscript𝑍subscript𝐤0superscript𝑁12RELOP:similar-to italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-N POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim Z_{{\bf k}_{0}}N^{1/2} and δ⁢n𝐤(1)∝-(1+sign⁢qx)/qxproportional-to𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐤11signsubscript𝑞𝑥subscript𝑞𝑥italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:proportional-to ADDOP:minus OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus sign italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)}\propto-(1+{\rm sign}\,q_{x})/q_{x}. We interpret this result as an indication of an emerging large Fermi surface at discontinuities at points 𝐤0subscript𝐤0bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf k}_{0}, not lines in the BZ.

The anomalous structure at 𝐤=(±π/2,±π/2)𝐤plus-or-minus𝜋2plus-or-minus𝜋2bold-k RELOP:equals OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:){\bf k}=(\pm\pi/2,\pm\pi/2) is clearly seen in Fig. 2, where δ⁢n𝐤(1)𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)} is shown for Z𝐤⁢t/J∼1similar-tosubscript𝑍𝐤𝑡𝐽1italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t MULOP:divide italic-J RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1Z_{\bf k}t/J\sim 1 and γ→1→𝛾1italic-gamma ARROW:to NUMBER:1\gamma\to 1. The Green’s function is here approximated with the non-interacting expression, G𝐤0⁢(ω)≈-1/ωsubscript𝐺subscript𝐤0𝜔1𝜔italic-G POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-omega CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-omegaG_{{\bf k}_{0}}(\omega)\approx-1/\omega. It should be noted that δ⁢n𝐤(1)𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)} exhibits at γ=1𝛾1italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\gamma=1 also a (weak) singularity (>1absent1RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1>1). However, the n𝐤subscript𝑛𝐤italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{\bf k} sum rule is still exactly satisfied. In Fig. 2 is for the purpose of presentation δ⁢n𝐤(1)𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)} truncated to -6<δ⁢n𝐤(1)<16𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐤11ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 RELOP:less-than italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1-6<\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)}<1.

In the present work we considered the electron momentum distribution function for a single hole in AFM and possibly relevant to underdoped cuprates. Non-analytic properties encountered in Eq. (4) are an evidence of the emerging large Fermi surface at 𝐤∼(±π/2,±π/2)similar-to𝐤plus-or-minus𝜋2plus-or-minus𝜋2bold-k RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:){\bf k}\sim(\pm\pi/2,\pm\pi/2) coexisting, however, with a ’hole pocket’ type of a Fermi surface. As long-range AFM order is destroyed by doping, ’hole-pocket’ contributions should disappear while the singularity in δ⁢n𝐤𝛿subscript𝑛𝐤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k} could persist. We thus interpret this result as relevant for the understanding of the electronic structure found recently with ARPES experiments in uderdoped cuprates [1], where only portions of a large Fermi surface close to 𝐤∼𝐤0similar-to𝐤subscript𝐤0bold-k RELOP:similar-to bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\bf k}\sim{\bf k}_{0} were seen.

img.figcaption: Figure 1: P=∑m=0∞Am⁢Am+1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑚0subscript𝐴𝑚subscript𝐴𝑚1italic-P RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:endP=\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\sqrt{A_{m}A_{m+1}}, full line, and 1-Z01subscript𝑍0NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end1-Z_{0}, dashed line, determine all momentum dependence of δ⁢n𝐤𝛿subscript𝑛𝐤italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k} in the SCBA with γ=0𝛾0italic-gamma RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\gamma=0.

br.figcaption: Figure 2: Perturbative result δ⁢n𝐤(1)𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑛𝐤1italic-delta italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\delta n_{\bf k}^{(1)}, Eq. (4), for Z𝐤⁢t/J∼1similar-tosubscript𝑍𝐤𝑡𝐽1italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start bold-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-t MULOP:divide italic-J RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1Z_{\bf k}t/J\sim 1.

li.span: Z.-X. Shen and D. S. Dessau, Phys. Rep. 253, 1 (1995); B. O. Wells et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 74, 964 (1995); D. S. Marshall et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 76, 4841 (1996).
S. Schmitt-Rink et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 60, 2793 (1988).
A. Ramšak and P. Prelovšek, Phys. Rev. B 42, 10415absent\! (1990).
G. Martínez and P. Horsch, Phys. Rev. B 44, 317 (1991).
A. Ramšak and P. Horsch, Phys. Rev. B 48, 10559 (1993); ibid. 57, 4308 (1998).
A. Ramšak, I. Sega, and P. Prelovšek, cond-mat/9910419.
